President @CyrilRamaphosa will deliver a message of support to the 18th Nelson Mandela annual lecture delivered by @UN Secretary General @antonioguterres under the theme “Tackling the Inequality Pandemic: A New Social Contract for a New Era”. #MandelaDay https://t.co/dVU9X4MeLy

President #Ramaphosa: On the 18th of July every year, we celebrate @NelsonMandela’s life. A life lived in the service of others.
We celebrate the triumph of the human spirit over adversity.
#MandelaDay https://t.co/J0pFLouKqB
President #Ramaphosa: On this day, we perform 67 minutes of service in memory of a man who believed that just one small act of kindness can make the world of difference in the life of others.

President #Ramaphosa: Nelson Rolihlahla Mandela was one of the greatest leaders of our time.
He was a hero of South Africa’s liberation struggle. But he was not ours alone. He belonged to peace and freedom loving peoples everywhere.
President #Ramaphosa: His great personal sacrifices, his service to his country, and his commitment to advancing freedom made him the father of not just our nation, but of every nation.

President #Ramaphosa: It has been a decade since the first International Nelson Mandela Day was proclaimed by the United Nations; a proud testament to global solidarity in pursuit of the ideals Madiba held dear.

President #Ramaphosa: His example serves as an ever-present reminder of the importance of principled servant leadership.
His legacy in fighting apartheid is all the more relevant today as the spectre of racial disharmony has raised its ugly head in many parts of the world.
President #Ramaphosa: Across the world people are rising up and taking a firm stand against racism, injustice and inequality that has become systematic and entrenched.

President #Ramaphosa: In his memory, we must strive all the harder to build societies rooted in mutual respect, tolerance and perhaps most importantly, founded on justice and reconciliation.
This year we celebrate #MandelaDay in the shadow of a global pandemic. https://t.co/48Cvtvzuco

President #Ramaphosa: Coronavirus has devastated the lives of many people and and the livelihoods of societies across the world.
Yet, inspired by Mandela’s spirit of compassion and care, this pandemic has revived the bonds of solidarity amongst the nations of the world.

President #Ramaphosa: The outpouring of goodwill has been on a scale rarely witnessed in modern times. We have been able to put aside our superficial differences and have worked together in the spirit of solidarity.

President #Ramaphosa: The compassion and solidarity that has been demonstrated to the vulnerable and the poor across the world has restored our faith in humanity.
There have been donations of personal protective equipment, medical supplies and food parcels to those in need.

President #Ramaphosa: Rich countries are helping poorer countries. Developed nations are supporting developing ones.
Individuals are giving of their time, their efforts and their resources to aid the less fortunate who have been left vulnerable by the pandemic.

President #Ramaphosa: Madiba inspired us to recognize the immense power within us to change the world,  and to see ourselves as agents of transformation.
#MandelaDay
President #Ramaphosa: Just as we put our collective energies into turning the tide against #COVID19, let us also deepen our collaboration to address humankind’s most pressing challenges.

President #Ramaphosa: The @UN Secretary-General Mr. @AntónioGuterres has chosen for this year’s  Nelson Mandela Annual Lecture the topic: “Tackling the inequality pandemic: a new social contract for a new era.” #MandelaDay https://t.co/I7Ky82yArW

President #Ramaphosa: This is a theme that goes to the heart of the immense task before us.
A new era is indeed upon us. It is the world of which Nelson Mandela dreamed; where a powerful vision matched by action can change the world.

President #Ramaphosa: Let us press ahead with our quest to realize a world free of poverty and inequality, violence, persecution, disease and suffering. We understand only too well that if only some of us are free, none of us are free.

President #Ramaphosa: Let us make every effort to overcome lack of access to education; poverty and underdevelopment; food insecurity and hunger; climate change; and the scourge of gender-based violence.

President #Ramaphosa: Let the upliftment of the material and spiritual condition of our fellow all human beings be our foremost preoccupation. At a time when it seems there is so much upheaval, fear and doubt in the world, we still cherish the hope of a better tomorrow.

President #Ramaphosa: Even as we live in these troubled times, it was Nelson Mandela who taught us to remain courageous and persevere. We have the utmost faith in in our collective resilience, and in our ability to come together in pursuit of the greater good.
President #Ramaphosa: We will rise above the devastation wrought by this pandemic. We stand firm in the cause of our common humanity, but more especially, in the cause of the most vulnerable.

President #Ramaphosa: I wish everyone a meaningful International #MandelaDay. This is a theme that goes to the heart of the immense task before us. A new era is indeed upon us. It is the world of which Madiba dreamed, where a powerful vision matched by action can change the world https://t.co/degSrmq4xC

#HappeningNow - President @DannyFaure announcing measures to address the #COVID19 situation in #Seychelles https://t.co/m7CB4E2UJv

#COVID19measuresSC #PrivateSector "Government will guarantee the salaries of all employees in the private sector for the months of April, May and June. A total of SCR1.2 billion has been budgeted for this intervention. Government will not approve any redundancies."

#COVID19measuresSC #PrivateSector "Government will increase the budgetary allocation for the Agency of Social Protection so that they are able to support those who are affected. A sum of SCR30 million will be allocated to the Agency for Social Protection."

#COVID19measuresSC #PrivateSector "Government will increase the budgetary allocation for the Unemployment Relief Scheme (URS). A sum of SCR10 million will be allocated to the Department of Employment."

#COVID19measuresSC #PrivateSector  "In exceptional cases, loan repayments will be reduced for a period of 6 months, following work that the Central Bank has done with the commercial banks. If necessary, an individual can get a moratorium for loan repayments over this period."

#COVID19measuresSC #PrivateSector
'Government will provide financial assistance to these struggling businesses to ensure that all of their employees are paid in April, May and June.'

#COVID19measuresSC #PrivateSector
'Given that Government will be providing businesses with the means to pay their employees, no redundancies will be approved by the Department of Employment.'

#COVID19measuresSC #PrivateSector 'loan repayments will be reduced for a period of 6 months, following work between the Central Bank and commercial banks. In exceptional cases, there will be a moratorium on loan repayments during this period.'

#COVID19measuresSC #PrivateSector 'For those businesses that find themselves in need of more liquidity, the Ministry of Finance and Central Bank are finalising a framework by which these businesses will be able to access credit quickly and more affordably.'

#COVID19measuresSC #BusinessTaxes:
'All tax payments due in March are being postponed to September 2020. CSR, TMT, and Business Tax payments for April, May and June are also being postponed to September 2020.'

#COVID19measuresSC #PrivateSector 'for the agriculture sector... everything that is produced can be bought (if the farmer wishes to sell to STC). Furthermore, Government identified 14 plots of land that will be made available to the Farmer’s Association for further production'
#COVID19measuresSC #PrivateSector 'interest rates for investment loans in agriculture or fisheries will be reduced to 1%.'

#COVID19measuresSC #PrivateSector 'following the decision of Government to maintain the electricity tariff for the public sector, the commercial sector will also benefit from a reduction of more than 25 cents per unit on their electricity tariffs.'

#COVID19measuresSC #PrivateSector 'contributions that employers are required to make toward the Seychelles Pension Fund – the 3% on the salary of their employees – for April, May and June will now be due in September 2020.'

New Year Message 31 December 2019 
https://t.co/0Dw5CXAiNp

Fellow Namibians,
Good evening, 

Tonight, as you gather with family and friends in anticipation, and with expectant hearts the dawn of the Year 2020, I wish each one of you a happy, healthy and fulfilling New Year.

As we enter the Year 2020, we pause to undertake personal and collective introspection. We pause to take stock of the successes we have scored, the opportunities we have missed, the lessons we have learned and the improvements we need to make.

You will agree with me that 2019 was a challenging year for our country. Despite the difficulties of 2019, as a resilient nation we have much to be proud of and have reasons to look forward to a better 2020.

Fellow Namibians,
Just over a month ago, Namibians participated in the 2019 Presidential and National Assembly Elections. As I stated during the rallies, this is not a war between enemies – but a contest between brothers and sisters.

Without doubt, our 7th democratic elections were one of the most fiercely contested since our Independence in 1990. The spirited contestation by respective candidates and parties notwithstanding, the elections were conducted in a climate and spirit of peace.

In democratic contestation, there are winners and losers. 
I thank the people of Namibia, who are the true victors, for having ensured, through their maturity and orderly conduct, that Namibian democracy continues to mature.
As Government, we have listened to the cries and calls of the sovereigns. We have heard you. You pointed out areas of improvement to us.

I call on New Year’s revelers nationwide to act responsibly. Excessive alcohol consumption is often the fuel for disorderly and violent conduct. Bars and shebeen owners should adhere to legal business hours, and law-enforcement agencies should act against violators.

At this hour, at the cusp of 2019, I call on all of you to embrace the promise of 2020 by behaving in a mature and responsible manner. Wherever you are headed, make sure you arrive alive. Be safe, care for one another.

Let us hold hands as we enter 2020, ready to build a better and caring Namibian House.
 
I wish you all Happy New Year. 

May God continue to bless the Republic of Namibia. https://t.co/Zn6EeRh7oc

It has been 76 days since we mobilized Namibia’s National Response to COVID-19, following confirmation of the Index Case on March 13, 2020. #COVID19 #NamLockdown #Stage3
Our country has to date recorded 22 confirmed cases, which have all been classified to be sporadic and travel related.
There has been up to this point, no incidence of community transmission in Namibia. Of the persons diagnosed with the #coronavirus, 14 have recovered and are reunited with their families.

Namibia sustained a 45-day period of zero new infections, until a rise in new infections which began on 20 May 2020. Since then, there have been six (6) new confirmed cases. #COVID19 #NamLockdown #Stage3
All the new cases have been placed into isolation facilities at /Kharas, Hardap and Erongo regions. The identification, contact tracing, testing and quarantine of exposed individuals, is ongoing.
Despite the measures that we have put in place, let us maintain the respect of human dignity and express compassion towards one another as Namibians. #COVID19 #NamLockdown #Stage3
I ask that our men and women in uniform who have done a sterling job during this difficult time, desist from using heavy-handedness in enforcing the Regulations. #COVID19 #NamLockdown #Stage3

Midnight on Monday 01st June 2020 all 14 regions, with the exception of the Walvis Bay Local Authority Area, will transit from STAGE 2 to more moderate precautions under STAGE 3, until 29 June 2020, for a period of 28 days or two incubation periods.

With the increase of the public gathering limit to 50 people under stage 3, we look forward to an increased presence of our church leaders, clergy and members of congregations in helping to bring the message of hope as well as much needed relief to the afflicted.

The public is urged to support Government action by not becoming complacent, but by complying with the Regulations and cooperating with authorities to safeguard the collective health of the Nation. #COVID19 #NamLockdown #Stage3

Services to be suspended to prevent spread of #CoronaVirus #COVIDー19 

*1.0 Entertainment, Public Events and Works:
1.1 All bottle stores, pubs, bars and clubs are closed, including in all hospitality facilities.
1.2 All cultural events and activities
1.3 All sporting activities
1.4 Weddings, engagement ceremonies, bridal showers, send offs and all gatherings of public and social nature are suspended.

1.7 All construction works are suspended. #COVIDー19

2.0 Markets
2.1 Local Authorities shall designate make-shift markets and also regulate the conduct of business in public markets.
2.2 All mobile markets are suspended.
3.0 Religious Gatherings:

All religious gathering are suspended.

Other activities which have to take place or continue, while observing strict social distance restrictions & #COVIDー19 COVID-19 hygiene & sanitary measures: 
(a)  Harvesting of crops & grazing of livestock shall be allowed
(b) Operation of maize mills #CoronaVirus

#Malawi declares a 21 day lockdown #coronavirus #COVID19

Measures to be implemented and enforced during the duration of the #coronavirus lockdown. #Covid_19 

1. Markets and Supermarkets 
 
1.1. All central markets are suspended. Fresh foods, fruits, relish and other requirements may be sourced from locality markets.

In places where there are no markets, the Local Council, in conjunction with traditional or block leaders, will identify and announce the markets that will be used in vicinity. These markets will operate from 6.00 am to 2.00 pm [daily] or [on prescribed days].
1.2. Local Councils, in conjunction with Ministry responsible for Trade, shall identify & license persons to supply essential goods and services to local markets and shops.

In addition, the same authorities will establish supply chains for easy movement of goods from wholesalers to local markets

1.3. The District Commissioners or Chief Executive Officers, as the case may be, shall prescribe the supermarket that may be opened in Local Councils.

In light of this declaration, the following are prescribed 

2. Movement of people 
2.1. Movement of any person other than of persons exempt under the Rules or under circumstances prescribed thereunder is prohibited.

Persons in employment are not allowed to move except where they are supplying essential goods and services. Where possible, employers are encouraged to stay at or work from home. Movement for acquisition of basic necessities shall be restricted.

2.2. Any person desirous of getting an essential service out of his or her locality shall get a permit from the Local Council or any delegated person to issue such permits by the Local Council. In the same vein, any person desirous of getting an essential service outside his or..

her district shall get a permit from the Chief Executive Officer or District Commissioner. Local Councils shall communicate the manner of applying for the permits within their jurisdiction, including telephone numbers through which information may be shared regarding the permits.

3. Entertainment, Public Events and Works
3.1. All bottle stores, pubs, bars and clubs, including in all hospitality facilities, shall be closed.
3.2. All cultural events and activities are suspended.
3.3. All sporting activities are suspended. #COVID19 #coronavirus

3.4. Weddings, engagement ceremonies, bridal showers, send offs and all gatherings of public and social in nature are suspended.
3.5. Funerals shall comply with social distance restrictions  and be attended by a maximum number of fifty people......
....In this case, observation of #COVID19 sanitary and hygienic measures is a requirement at all funerals. Funeral ceremonies shall be conducted in the shortest time possible.

3.6. Fast food outlets, restaurants and public eating places shall be closed to the public except for take away services. All residents in hospitality facilities shall be served in their rooms. All persons eating within facilities shall not use enclosed spaces to have meals.

4. Gatherings
4.1 All gatherings of more than ten people are suspended.

#COVID19

5. Transport 
5.1. Public transport (minibuses, tricycles, taxis, bicycles, motorcycles & taxis) will only be allowed primarily to offer services to essential services staff and cater for emergencies from 5.00 am to 9.00am in the mornings & from 4.00 pm to 7.00 pm in the evenings

5.2. No public transport vehicle shall be allowed to loiter or linger around for passengers outside these hours. 

5.3. No public transport operator shall operate a vehicle without proper ventilation. #COVID19 #coronavirus

5.4. All public transport vehicles shall ensure that social distancing is observed and sanitary and hygienic materials are provided on board. 

5.5. All operators of public service vehicles and crew shall at all times, use personal protective equipment.

5.6. Air transport services remain suspended with the exception of supplies for essential goods and services and returning passengers. In all cases, air transport services shall be offered with prior arrangements with the Minister.

5.7. Locomotive passenger transport shall be allowed to operate between Liwonde and Nayuchi only. However, locomotive goods transport shall continue operating without any restrictions but shall follow #COVID19 sanitary and hygienic measures.

5.8. Water transport services will only operate between Nkhatabay and Likoma. 

5.9. All other private and institutional vehicles are also suspended except with permission from enforcement authorities.
5.10. Persons performing essential services or supplying essentials goods shall be given a permit by the District Commissioner or Chief Executive Officer or delegated officers. #COVID19 #coronavirus

(b) Where a camp is not provided for on site, transport is provided for workers to travel from a camp to the construction site; or

(c) The works involve the operation of a single operator machine or plant at the construction site. #COVID19 #coronavirus

7. Other services to be allowed 

7.1. Harvesting of crops within prescribed hours and with strict observance of sanitary and hygienic conditions. 

7.2. Grazing of livestock within prescribed hours and with strict observance of sanitary and hygienic conditions. #COVID19

7.3. Operation of maize mills within prescribed hours and with strict observance of sanitary and hygienic conditions.

7.4. Marketing of agricultural products including tobacco auction floors.

7.5. And all essential services as provided for under these Rules. #coronavirus

8. Mitigation
Government is aware of the hardship and inconvenience that the Lockdown will inflict on the population during the 21days and afterwards. On 20th March, 2020 President  @APMutharika declared a state of disaster over #COVID19 pandemic & consequent to this declaration.

the mitigation and relief measures provided for under the Disaster Preparedness and Relief Act (Cap. 33:05) have been invoked in order to avert the consequent suffering of Malawians in form of social safety nets to vulnerable groups who live a hand to mouth type of subsistence.
I shall in due course announce the specific measures that Government shall implement.  #COVID19 #coronavirus

9. Enforcement

9.1 These measures shall be enforced by enforcement officers as prescribed under the Rules.
9.2 The Malawi Defence Force, the Malawi Police Service and the Department of Immigration and Citizenship Services shall be deployed to ensure strict compliance with these measures.
9.3 Local Councils remain empowered under the Public Health Act to commence civil and criminal proceedings in order to enforce the measures prescribed under these Rules. #COVID19 #coronavirus

The Supreme Court of Appeal Friday upheld a ruling by the High Court sitting as Constitutional court to nullify the May 21 Presidential election results and order a fresh election

The 7 judge panel led by Chief Justice Andrew Nyirenda sitting in Lilongwe made a 'unanimous' judgement, which among others included an order that newly registered voters will not be allowed to vote and that MEC should use the same voters roll as used in the disputed election.
MEC had appealed against the Constitutional Court ruling which nullified last year's presidential poll citing irregularities in the conduct of the vote.

Acting Minister of ICT Manqoba Khumalo has announced that Set Top Boxes (Sgujana) will now cost E100 in a bid to ensure that most Emaswati have access to local radio & television channels. https://t.co/gW15zsTk1l

Minister Khumalo: "When Set Top Boxes were introduced in 2014, Government subsidised them to cost E250 each. Now, Government is working to curb the spread of #COVID19 & one of the best ways of doing this is disseminating up to date information via print & electronic media." https://t.co/OqPPboDWhw

Minister Khumalo: "We hope that this will also assist more learners access lessons through ongoing radio & TV programs. His Majesty King Mswati III has called on Commonwealth countries to work together to defeat #COVID19. His Majesty has been addressing the Commonwealth #COVID19 Leaders Virtual Meeting through Prime Minister Ambrose Mandvulo Dlamini this afternoon. https://t.co/Jmhqj5CS0y

HMK: "As a country, we encourage the spirit of working together to find common solutions. In unity we will be able to put this pandemic behind us and help reignite our economies to create wealth and prosperity for all our people & future generations." https://t.co/4Mwe7ey2cp

HMK: "Eswatini has had to tackle #COVID19 at a time when we had made notable strides in fighting HIV, Malaria & TB. We've had to realign our national budget. All efforts have been targeted at tracing, testing, isolating & treating all positive cases in order to flatten the curve.

HMK: "The introduction of a partial lockdown in March enabled our health system to strengthen through a number of intervention programmes which includes intensive recruitment & training of health workers, increasing the number of beds & procuring appropriate PPE."

HMK: "We have also established social welfare programmes to help our citizens who have been laid off, help SMEs & informal traders who have lost business and more importantly, to provide food for some of our citizens."

Minister of Health Lizzie Nkosi announces three new #COVID19 deaths in Eswatini, taking the total number of #COVID19 deaths in Eswatini to 11. "May their souls rest in peace."

New cases: 36
Total cases: 781

New recoveries: 2
Total recoveries: 372

New deaths: 3
Total deaths: 11 https://t.co/N69ZJlfPZI

Minister Nkosi: "We note with concern the increase in numbers of deaths of confirmed #COVID19 patients as a result of co-existing medical conditions such as Diabetes Mellitus, Hypertension, Cardiac Disease & Asthma."
Minister Nkosi: "10 out of the 11 deaths had either been newly diagnosed with one or more of the above conditions or had been found to have poor control of these chronic conditions."

Minister Nkosi: "Nine out of the 11 deaths are males. We therefore urge the public, especially males, to do medical check-ups regularly, at least once a year & those diagnosed with a chronic illness should adhere to the treatment as advised by health workers."

Minister of Tourism Moses Vilakati has congratulated the newly appointed members of the National Biosafety Advisory Committee on their appointment into office. "This appointment has been done in accordance with section 6 of the Biosafety Act of 2012." https://t.co/65QxCVsyZM

Minister Vilakati: "The main function of the National Biosafety Advisory Committee is to conduct risk assessments and to provide scientific advice & technical assistance to the Eswatini Environment Authority. We recognize the expertise & the wealth of experience you bring." https://t.co/MD4tTanh46

Minister Vilakati: "The regulation of biotechnology & its products is complex as this subject matter is not static: it evolves day-after-day as developers exploit new knowledge to improve lives or even make profits through this technology."

Minister Vilakati: "The constant development of applied techniques in modern biotechnology bring about various benefits and also pose concerns which have to be considered in adapting & implementing the biosafety legislation." https://t.co/wG8RH2UJFq

Minister Vilakati: "It is against this backdrop therefore that a team of experts who are well trained in the various disciplines that relate to this technology is appointed by the Ministry to advise the EEA on the regulation of the technology in Eswatini." https://t.co/0Tj8JWhcst

National Biosafety Advisory Committee Members: Professor Cebsile Magagula (Chair), Dr. Ngaka Shongwe, Dr. Robert Thwala, Mr. Similo Mavimbela, Mr. Enock Dlamini, Mr. Boy Matse, Ms. Tibuyile Ziyane, Mr. Sipho Shongwe & Ms. Nobuhle Dlamini.

Eswatini is today bidding farewell to four Taiwanese medical specialists who have spent the past two months helping boost the country's #COVID19 response. Minister of Health Lizzie Nkosi: "On behalf of His Majesty’s Government, I thank you for your selflessness." #TaiwanCanHelp https://t.co/PwFVbhGzRs

Minister Nkosi: "You volunteered to leave a safer environment in Taiwan & come to Eswatini, exposing yourselves to #COVID19. You made a decision from the very beginning to teach, train and mentor our teams & furtner refine our case management protocols."

Minister Nkosi: "You made a huge difference in decreasing the infection rate of health workers at the Lubombo Hospital & further helped train our health workers on the correct use of PPE & equipment. You also extended your stay in Eswatini by 4 weeks, underlining your commitment.
Minister: "You have played a big role in saving the lives of many Emaswati and we wish you well on your journey home."

Minister of Economic Planning Dr. Tambo Gina has today launched the UNFPA-published State of the World Population Report. This year's report is themed: "Against my will: defying the practices that harm women and girls & undermine equality." https://t.co/obNtrVQlL9

Minister Gina: "The report identifies issues of priority globally in the areas of population & development. This year's theme is meant to sensitize stakeholders against harmful practices on women and girls which are still prevalent in some of our communities."

Minister Gina: "Eswatini is signatory to UN conventions which seek to protect human rights including those of women & children. We have domesticated legislation, ensuring that the rights are enshrined in our Statutes, including the Child Protection Act, SODV Act & Gender Policy."

Minister Gina: "The time has come for the complete elimination of harmful practices against women & girls. Communities which still practise such are urged to desist since their practices directly affect the contributions towards economic growth & development." https://t.co/nSIfJ4NLtG

Acting Head of @UNFPAEswatini Margaret Thwala-Tembe: "This year’s report makes a case about three most harmful practices in society namely; female genital mutilation, son preference and child marriage. It calls upon communities to rise up against these practices." https://t.co/GYV808ZRo4

Government has partnered with MTN Eswatini to launch an e-payment platform for company registrations using Mobile Money. The platform is available on Government's *468# channel & will accommodate other Government services in the future. https://t.co/yWevkszQMd

Commerce Minister Manqoba Khumalo: "This comes at a time when the whole world is trying to overcome the effects of #COVID19, particularly on business. As Governments transition towards the new normal, this has required them to come up with innovative adaptation techniques." https://t.co/ufR9uUssQ0

Minister Khumalo: "The launch of this e-platform supports cashless transactions and will lessen transaction costs through the elimination of transport fees & the long queues that have become synonymous with most Government transactions."

MTN CEO Wandile Mtshali: "This integration of the payment system will help Emaswati stay safe and enable them to make their Government payments 24 hours a day, seven days a week. The cherry on top is that they can make payments from the comfort of their home or workspace. https://t.co/dh9ya8aWyD

MTN CEO: "The gradual reopening of the economy means that some service areas will be congested, something that is undesirable in the time of #COVID19. The use of this service is a calculated way of mitigating long queues and complying with health guidelines."

How it works: Dial *468# then select a language. From there, select the Ministry of Commerce and then select 'Company registration.' Once details have been filled in, confirm payment with your Mobile Money Pin. You will then receive an SMS notification confirming the payment.

Prime Minister Ambrose Mandvulo Dlamini has announced the reopening of casinos, game rooms, gambling facilities, auctioneers, gyms, health & beauty spas as well as cinemas with effect from 13 July. “It is crucial to insist that compliance to health guidelines is not negotiable.” https://t.co/Hdp7bcGagl

Prime Minister: “The gradual reopening up of the economy necessitates an update in guidelines for the operation of all transport modes. Government, in consultation with stakeholders, has therefore issued new transport guidelines which are effective on Monday 6 July 2020.”

PM: “Seated carrying capacity for public transport is permitted up to 80% with compulsory sanitisation for all passengers. This is the responsibility of each transport operator. Wearing of masks for all vehicle occupants is compulsory.”

PM: “Carrying capacity of scholar transport is permitted up to 80%, with adherence to health measures such as sanitization & usage of masks at all times. Dedicated scholar transport will be provided where possible, especially in hot spot areas.”

The Prime Minister has also announced a review of regulations guiding the gathering of people. “Government in collaboration with stakeholders has issued new guidelines for religious gatherings, wedding ceremonies, funerals & community meetings with effect from 19 July 2020.” https://t.co/003GwVKpfS
PM: “Places of worship will need to obtain a compliance permit from the Ministry of Home Affairs in order to operate. Assessments will be made for each applicant to determine readiness.”

PM: “Worshipers are strictly required to observe two metres social distancing, wear masks and refrain from laying of hands, touching or hugging, among others. The full observance of 2 metres distance between individuals will determine the numbers allowed indoors.”

PM: “The number of people attending a wedding ceremony shall not exceed 100 people if held in an open space. The number of people attending a funeral shall not exceed 100 when the funeral is held in an open space. Community meetings must be attended by a maximum 100 people.” https://t.co/m2WRu9mkf5

PM: “The duration of each session of religious gatherings, weddings, funerals & community meetings must not exceed two hours. At all gatherings, an attendance register with contact details of all attendees, their next of kin & residential addresses for ease of contact tracing.”

PM: “Those over 60 and those with chronic diseases are advised to avoid attending public gatherings. The consumption of alcohol in any gathering is prohibited. Where food is served it shall be in the form of prepared parcels.”

The PM has further announced initiatives undertaken by Government in preparation for the gradual reopening of schools starting with form 5’s & completing tertiary classes on Monday. “Government has filled all admin positions for the smooth operation of schools when they resume.” https://t.co/JGjr1K072j

PM: “Government has renewed contracts for teachers and filled vacancies for 22 Head Teachers at all levels, including 170 teachers at secondary level. Government has also assigned Ministers, MPs, Health & Education Officials to inspect the level of preparedness in schools.” https://t.co/NOd896llkG

PM: “We also commend teachers & head teachers for returning to their duty stations to assist in the preparedness exercise. I appeal to parents, teachers & the transportation sector to cooperate with Government as we embark on this delicate re-opening exercise.”

PM: “My appeal is extended to all the students returning to class to strictly adhere to health precautions. We urge parents to also ensure that their children are well advised on all the health protocols.”

In terms of Health-focused interventions, the PM has announced a new set of activities to mitigate the spread of the virus. “Government is placing special focus on the Manzini region. There has been an increased training resulting in a decline in healthcare workers’ infections.” https://t.co/DvKplmnk9c

PM: “Starting next week, additional activities will be implemented in the Manzini region hot spots in an effort to curb transmission including: door to door health education & promotion, cluster testing, increased screening in schools & engagement with the Transport sector.”
PM’s Statement in full: https://t.co/HPfu1OVCVn https://t.co/vIRH5zHs0k

Prime Minister Ambrose Mandvulo Dlamini announced new measures & interventions in Government's #COVID19 response yesterday afternoon. Here is a pick of some of the major interventions: https://t.co/AhYfAL7KzU

More Businesses to reopen from 13 July:

Health interventions:

● Door to door health education & promotion.

● Cluster testing.

Health interventions:

● Increased monitoring & screening in Manzini schools.
  
● Engagement with Manzini region Transport sector.

Review of gatherings guidelines from 19 July:

●Places of worship need to obtain a permit from Home Affairs. Two metres social distance to be observed, wear masks & no physical contact.

●100 people can attend funerals, weddings & community meetings if held in open spaces.

Review of gatherings guidelines from 19 July:

●No night vigils allowed, all gatherings should not exceed two hours & 2 metres social distance to be observed. 

●Details of all attendees should be kept for ease of contact tracing.

● Food should be served in prepared parcels.

Prime Minister Ambrose Mandvulo Dlamini says Eswatini's successful response to HIV & AIDS is an example of what can be achieved through collaboration. The country has surpassed the global target of 90-90-90 and reduced AIDS deaths & infections by 50% since 2010. https://t.co/ypwaW1bZ6d

The PM has been making a Virtual Address at the Launch of the @UNAIDS 2020 Global AIDS Report this afternoon. "We once lived through a wave of increasing new HIV infections & many dying from AIDS. Today, the UNAIDS report shows that we are on course to end AIDS by 2030."

PM: "Our success comes because of the extraordinary & innovative efforts taken by the country over the years. 95% of people living with HIV in Eswatini know their status and 95% of those are accessing treatment. Of those, 95% have achieved viral suppression."

PM: "We have reduced AIDS-related deaths by 50% from 6600 in 2010 to 2300 in 2019 & reduced new HIV infections by 50% from 13000 in 2010 to 6500 in 2019. We have been able to mobilize & reach young men who have played a vital role in breaking the cycle of new HIV  infections."

PM: "We have introduced innovations, reprogrammed our approaches to ensure that we tailor our responses in the right places. Our communities have taken the 
lead and they have helped to shape our response."

PM: "We are aiming for 100-100-100. In the coming years, we will expand our programmes on voluntary male circumcision, programmes to reach young women & girls, bring more innovations to our HIV prevention efforts and transform gender relations."

PM: "We have received support from our partners such as PEPFAR, Global Fund, UNAIDS & others. The #COVID19 pandemic response can learn from the AIDS movement. We must eradicate inequality. Everyone has a right to health, with dignity and respect and we have to make it happen."
PM's Statement in full: https://t.co/PoUbnxQMor

Prime Minister Ambrose Mandvulo Dlamini has announced that the first batch of Government #COVID19 payment for laid-off workers begins today with 1949 recipients. “Subsequent payments will be made every Friday until the current figure of laid off employees is exhausted.” https://t.co/qGfzX04gqm

PM: “The plan will later spread throughout the country. It will focus on education, finding cases, testing, treating, isolating and tracing contacts. We appeal for cooperation from the nation. We are also increasing the number of beds at Mavuso Isolation Centre.”

Prime Minister Ambrose Mandvulo Dlamini announced new measures in Government's response to #COVID19 yesterday, among them a six-point health plan for the Manzini region & the reopening of selected sporting activities. Read on for a recap of some of the major decisions announced: https://t.co/WLayWT5UT5

1. Reopening of select Sporting activities:

Government is beginning a phased reopening of sporting activities from Monday, starting with low-risk sport namely: Angling, Athletics, Cricket, Cue Sports, Cycling, Darts, Equestrian, Golf, Shooting, Tennis and Teqball.

2. First payment of Government relief for laid-off workers:

Government has begun dispatching #COVID19 Relief payments for all laid-off workers, starting with a total of 1949 recipients yesterday. Subsequent payments will be made every Friday.

3. Health six-point plan for Manzini Region:

Government is embarking on a ‘Door to Door Campaign’ contained in a six-point plan to halt the spread of #COVID19 to start in Manzini & Hhohho, focusing on education, finding cases, testing, treating, isolating & tracing contacts.

4. Successful implementation of Food relief program:

More than 330 826 people have benefited from the food assistance program, exceeding the initially targeted 301 762 beneficiaries. The program will continue in July while 50 boreholes have been rehabilitated countrywide.

5. Successful reopening of schools:

Before their opening on 06 July, 275 schools were supplied with masks, sanitizers, liquid soap, and water tanks & teachers will be provided with face shields to reinforce their safety.

6. Plan to avoid possible fuel shortages:

In noting the volatility of fuel supply from South Africa, Government will work with oil companies to increase fuel volume importation from Mozambique. Government is also continuing to cushion local fuel price increases.

Commerce & Labour Ministers Manqoba Khumalo & Makhosi Vilakati have today visited the Premier Eswatini Mill to ascertain quality control measures employed by Premier in the interest of consumer protection. This follows recent consumer complaints on the company's bread quality. https://t.co/D2uuBuK4Ee

Minister Khumalo: "We were worried after the complaints last week &  wanted to find out what the problem was & further get assurances that such wouldn't happen again. It's good if the issue has been identified & going forward, high levels of quality control should be maintained." https://t.co/ldWk8rqCbc

Premier Eswatini Reps.: "We have identified the source of the problem & rectified it. We traced it to the wheat we used. While this is not harmful to the consumer, we will ensure that it does not happen again. We have already engaged clients who submitted their complaints." https://t.co/W3pPEohbce

[WATCH LIVE]: Prime Minister Ambrose Mandvulo Dlamini receives #COVID19 aid from the European Union.  https://t.co/ybzWcP9yUn

Prime Minister Ambrose Dlamini has this morning received E46.6 million from @EUinEswatini Ambassador Esmeralda Hernandez Aragones that will go towards a food assistance program to counter the effects of #COVID19. This support will be channeled through the Red Cross & the WFP. https://t.co/wYvr4sT0k0

Prime Minister: “The EU is showing, yet again, the kind of friend & collaborator it is to this Kingdom. It is important to inform the nation that the EU assistance will be channeled through Baphalali Eswatini Red Cross and the World Food Programme (WFP).” https://t.co/I9o46Upm6O

PM: “This support is significant as it adds to the ongoing food assistance programme which has already benefited over 330 000 Emaswati. Through this gesture, Emaswati will get food and cash assistance for an extended period & our national food security will be stabilised.”

Ambassador Aragones: “This assistance is part of the bigger support the EU is providing to the #COVID19 response in Eswatini which amounts to E1.4 billion covering multiple sectors of society. The support cements the partnership the EU has with the Kingdom of Eswatini.” https://t.co/j3sJkFdc81

Ambassador Aragones: “When this project is implemented, it will run for the next eight months. It is earmarked to reach out to approximately 230 000 households & will involve cash-based transfers (CBT) and provision of food parcels to the most food insecure populations.”
